academicallyRecognized.title: Eugeniy Tyumentcev, Omsk State University
academicallyRecognized.text: I teach Software Engineering with Kotlin. We also have a separate Android Development course. So I can teach in a language that students can use in other courses.

academicallyRecognized.title: Eamonn De Leastar, Waterford Institute of Technology
academicallyRecognized.text: On numerous courses, where we proceed through Java to Kotlin, we are considering a Kotlin-first approach.

languageOfTheIndustry.title: Ryan Stansifer, Florida Institute of Technology
languageOfTheIndustry.text: Students are happy to have the chance to program in something they may have heard about.

languageOfTheIndustry.title: Károly Machalik, University of Pannonia
languageOfTheIndustry.text: The students are so happy. They can produce useful software quickly.

multiplatform.title: Jacob Mass, University of Tartu
multiplatform.text: Decrease in boilerplate helps us to quickly identify which fundamental Android concepts students are missing. The likelihood of issues arising due to some basic syntactic/language problems is lower, allowing students instead to focus on more fundamental software design matters.

easyToLearn.title: San Skulrattanakulchai, Gustavus Adolphus College
easyToLearn.text: My students think Kotlin is an easy language to learn. Some students have adopted Kotlin as their main programming language. They use it as their language of choice when they can choose a language for completing an assignment or project.

easyToLearn.title: Scott Stanchfield, Johns Hopkins University
easyToLearn.text: Nearly all my students have picked up Kotlin quite easily and really loved it, as compared with Java.

easyToLearn.title: Enrico Denti, University of Bologna
easyToLearn.text: I appreciate Kotlin`s diffusion, its innovation while being able to ‘stay in the mainstream’ to soften the learning curve, the way it supports key concepts – in short, its clarity and cleanness.

interoperable.title: David Vaughn, University of Missouri–St. Louis
interoperable.text: Kotlin is faster to develop and comprehend what is happening; near 100% backwards compatibility makes it easy to show in Java and translate into Kotlin while still utilizing every available library from Java; Students seem to understand it fairly quickly.

interoperable.title: Paulo Pereira, Lisbon Superior Engineering Institute (ISEL)
interoperable.text: For the upcoming Introductory Programming course, we chose Kotlin, because we wanted a language that targets the JVM and seamlessly interoperates with its ecosystem: a stack of utmost importance to our market.

supportsMultipleParadigms.title: Alexey Mitsyuk, HSE university
supportsMultipleParadigms.text: You are able to teach procedural programming for the very beginners without needing to describe classes. Thus, your course can be more consistent.

supportsMultipleParadigms.title: Fernando Magno Quintão Pereira, Federal University of Minas Gerais
supportsMultipleParadigms.text: Kotlin has strong support for object-oriented programming, and also support for functional programming.

supportsMultipleParadigms.title: San Skulrattanakulchai, Gustavus Adolphus College
supportsMultipleParadigms.text: My Kotlin students in fact understand OO concepts better than my Java students do.

modernConciseAndSafe.title: Nick Efford, University of Leeds
modernConciseAndSafe.text: Kotlin`s compactness is my favorite feature. I’ve translated a few of my Java programming courseworks into Kotlin and noticed that code typically shrinks to 50% of its original size. As a teacher, I also get some benefit from being able to use less code when showing students how to do things.

modernConciseAndSafe.title: Zaid Altahat, Northwestern University, University of Wisconsin–Parkside
modernConciseAndSafe.text: Simple syntax. Less code to get more done. At the same time Kotlin has advanced topics such as coroutines.

modernConciseAndSafe.title: Mark Zaslavskiy, ITMO University
modernConciseAndSafe.text: One of Kotlin’s advantages is a good combination of strong typing and nullability.

modernConciseAndSafe.title: Jeffrey Paone, Colorado School of Mines
modernConciseAndSafe.text: Fewer runtime errors are Kotlin’s advantage. Null safety is my favorite Kotlin feature.

preparesStudentsForCareers.title: Ted Herman, University of Iowa
preparesStudentsForCareers.text: Employment prospects and how the language will be on the resume are things to look at when choosing a language to teach.

preparesStudentsForCareers.title: Fernando Magno Quintão Pereira, Federal University of Minas Gerais
preparesStudentsForCareers.text: Students like the language. It`s less verbose than Java, for instance, and has more market appeal than OCaml and ML.

toolingAndLearningMaterials.title: Alexander Nozik, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
toolingAndLearningMaterials.text: JetBrains equipped Kotlin with the best available tooling to simplify development.

toolingAndLearningMaterials.title: Mariusz Nowostawski, Norwegian University of Science and Technology
toolingAndLearningMaterials.text: Go for it! You will love it. The language is mature, the IDE support is fantastic, the documentation is great.
